concept.title: Use case: Analyzing customer paths that led to a purchase
concept.shortdesc: This use case describes how a customer data analyst can use to examine customer paths that led to the purchase of a product. Insights gained from this analysis can be shared with customer experience designers, who can use them to design new customer experiences for future product launches.

section.title: Scenario
section.p: Last year, CityCool, a developer of consumer technology, unveiled a new electronic watch called SleekFit. After a profitable market response and positive feedback from consumers, CityCool is ready to launch Sleekﬁt 2.0. Anthony, CityCool's customer experience analyst, wants to support the Sleekﬁt 2.0 launch to help their emerging wearable products division meet their business goal of increasing revenue by 10%.

section.title: Configuring the report criteria
section.p: Anthony logs in to and enters criteria to focus his analysis. He specifies that he wants to see only the top five paths, ranked by the most traveled.

Next, Anthony decides to limit the results only to paths that ended in a cart purchase of the Sleekfit 1.0 product. He sets the look-back range to seven days to see all of the interactions that occurred during the seven days that led up to the purchase. Then, he runs the report.

section.title: Analyzing the results
section.p: The results show the top five most-traveled paths that led to a purchase of Sleekfit 1.0, and the channels that customers used along these paths. Anthony notices that many of the customers watched a promotional video about the Sleekfit 1.0, and then applied a special offer when they made the purchase.

section.title: Sharing insights
section.p: Anthony shares what he has learned with CityCool’s user experience design team. The customer experience designers can then use Journey Designer to design a storyboard template as the foundation for new customer experience designs for the Sleekfit 2.0 launch.
